text:
So there's this startup that I came across a few weeks ago. Last week, I sent a cold email to the CEO about my interest in working for them as a content manager or writer.

I managed to get a reply, and we also had a meeting yesterday.

The CEO told me the marketing team will reach out again for a series of interviews. I was also asked to send my resume and portfolio, which I did right away.

There's this question that the CEO asked, that I think I didn't perform well: What will you be doing for us (that's in terms of content writing and blogging, and what type of content do you suggest we work on)? This is a great question because they haven't had a content writer (this could be their first role)

So I'm thinking about sending a content plan as a follow up, after researching their website more. Like the types of content I would write about, how we could tackle distributing these content - social media and other forms, etc.

Do you think this is something I should do? And if so, what do you think I should also include?
I want to make it a bit comprehensive, but not too much.

Would really appreciate advice from the community.

elements.text:
So there's this startup that I came across a few weeks ago. Last week, I sent a cold email to the CEO about my interest in working for them as a content manager or writer.

I managed to get a reply, and we also had a meeting yesterday.

The CEO told me the marketing team will reach out again for a series of interviews. I was also asked to send my resume and portfolio, which I did right away.

There's this question that the CEO asked, that I think I didn't perform well: What will you be doing for us (that's in terms of content writing and blogging, and what type of content do you suggest we work on)? This is a great question because they haven't had a content writer (this could be their first role)

So I'm thinking about sending a content plan as a follow up, after researching their website more. Like the types of content I would write about, how we could tackle distributing these content - social media and other forms, etc.

Do you think this is something I should do? And if so, what do you think I should also include?
I want to make it a bit comprehensive, but not too much.

Would really appreciate advice from the community.

text: Hi Saibu! I think in the context of a conversation with the CEO, and at a company that doesn't have any content staff, I expect they were mostly interested in how content fits into a larger go-to-market and revenue strategy. I don't think you'd need a full content calendar with topics and ideas, but more your general strategy for your first 30 days, your first 6 months, and first year. Maybe you can identify some quick wins (sales collateral, high-engagement social posts, etc.) and long-term plays (SEO, brand building, etc.). At least that's how I'd think about it!

Maybe you can identify some quick wins (sales collateral, high-engagement social posts, etc.) and long-term plays (SEO, brand building, etc.). At least that's how I'd think about it!

text: Agree with <@U02AUPZ1CMA>. Bonus points if you put this plan into a presentation deck using their brand colours—small details show that you're detail oriented. If those details are their brand... well no one cares more about a brand than the people who made it :wink:

text:
Hi <@U02AUPZ1CMA> Yes, agree with this. Thanks very much. The CEO was interested in how content fits into their revenue strategy, but I think I didn't grasp that part well, until I thought about it after the meeting. I'll go with your suggestion on this.

Thanks for the bonus tip <@U01AHL8AGBB> Really appreciate this.
